humanum_full_description_en:
Oracle starts from "ç›®" from â—, â— is the outer frame that encloses the "ç›®", like the outline of the face, with eyes in the middle. The original meaning is face, face. "Said Wen": "The face, the face before the face. From the ğ¦£», like a human face. All faces are from the face."

Because the eyes are the most prominent organ of the face, Oracle uses "ç›®" to represent the head. The oracle bone inscriptions may be derived from "person retains the shape of the human body." "é¢" is not seen in the bronze inscriptions, but there are characters with "é¢" as the radical. This word is not from "ç›®" but from " ğ¦£» " (the original word of "é¦–") From â—, see Shi Yun Fang Yi. " Yan " and " mian " have the same meaning in ancient times, so the word " yan " starts from " mian " as the meaning symbol, see " mian ".

Oracle is used as the name of the country (see Xu Zhongshu). The strokes of the outer frame of the Chu bamboo slips were corrupted into " mortar ". " Mian " extended to mean facing, towards, "Shangbo Chu Zhushu II. "Rong Chengshi" Jane 14: "Yao south, Shun north."
humanum_short_description_en: The outline of an Oracle elephant face with eyes in the middle. The original meaning is face.

    Oracle starts from " ç›®" from â—, â— is the outer frame that encloses the " ç›®", like the outline of the face, with eyes in the middle. The original meaning is face, face. "Said Wen": "The face, the face before the face. From the ğ¦£», like a human face. All faces are from the face." Because the eyes are the most prominent organ of the face, Oracle uses " ç›®" to represent the head. The oracle bone inscriptions may be derived from "person retains the shape of the human body." " é¢" is not seen in the bronze inscriptions, but there are characters with " é¢" as the radical. This word is not from " ç›®" but from " ğ¦£»" (the original word of " é¦–") From â—, see Shi Yun Fang Yi. " Yan" and " mian" have the same meaning in ancient times, so the word " yan" starts from " mian" as the meaning symbol, see " mian". Oracle is used as the name of the country (see Xu Zhongshu). The strokes of the outer frame of the Chu bamboo slips were corrupted into " mortar". " Mian" extended to mean facing, towards, "Shangbo Chu Zhushu II. "Rong Chengshi" Jane 14: "Yao south, Shun north."

    miÃ n
    The front part of the head, face: face. face. face. Looking at each other.
    Face to face, towards: face. Facing the wall (a. Facing the wall; b. Buddhism refers to meditation practice facing the wall).
    The appearance of things: the ground. Face friends (superficial, non-sincere friends). Denomination (the amount of face value).
    Orientation, part: front. The opposite. One-sided. comprehensive. All-rounder.
    Quantifier, mostly used for flat objects: a drum.
    Meeting, directly connected: in person. Negotiable. Face to face. Erti Mianming ("Erti", holding your ears to exhort; "Mianming", instructing face to face, to describe eager teaching).
    Geometrically, it refers to the shape generated by the movement of the line, which has length, width and no thickness: plane. Qu (q?) surface.
    Flour made from grains, especially flour made from wheat: flour. pasta. bread.
    Powder: medicated noodles.
    Strip-shaped food made of flour and water: noodles.
    The food contains little fiber and is soft: this melon is very noodles.

    Radicals: é¢  (face)
    Meaning Mnemonic
    The face radical and the face kanji are the same! But this isn't just a face like the one you're looking at your computer/phone with. It's the surface kind of face too!
    The next time you look at your face, also notice how much surface area it has.
    Reading Mnemonic
    This face you're looking at, that has a lot of surface area, belongs to men (ã‚ã‚“). Not a single man, but all men put together. It's hundreds of thousands of men's faces in a row.
    Look at the face of all men put together. Measure how much surface area they all take up.
